publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

monogr.title: Dolarnys primerose. Or the first part of the passionate hermit : wherein is expressed the liuely passions of zeale and loue, with an alluding discourse to valours ghost. Both pleasant and profitable, if iudiciously read, and rightly vnderstood. Written by a practitioner in poesie, and a stranger amongst poets, which causeth him dread this sentence: Nihil ad parmenonis suem
monogr.author: Reynolds, John

lg.l: WHat should I scrape, or beg, at pardons gate,
With prostrate termes, to helpe my stranger rimes:
When as I know, that in this wau'ring state,
None well can please, these fickle enuious times.
Therefore I craue, no other boone but this,
Vpon my lines, let euery fancie deeme.
What please them best: well, meane, or flatte amisse,
No whit the worse, I will of them esteeme.
For enuious curres, will bawle at strangers true,
When neighbor theeues, vnseene may filch & steale:
But trustie mastifes, or by sent or view,
The priuie drifts, of both will soone reueale.
Then if the learned, seeke not to despite me,
Let Enuie barke, I know he cannot bite me.
